summary: the pack — a poem on house stark
body:
the pack — a poem on house stark

with soft fur and enchanting eyes

you may get lost in their beauty

yet behind the guise of loyalty

is shown to be a beast

the young wolf, with eyes of sky and fur of ginger

an appearance desired by many

yet his personality of honor and courage

is lost to his reckless desires

then the wolf of red, with looks the same as before

with a desperate heart

and wits to last her days

a moment with her is a lifetime of fun

or a last breath to others

the wolf of no name is just like the water

graceful, flowing, smooth

but under attack and the pressure comes down

it may be the last time you move

a wolf with all knowledge

of days of the past

and possibly the future as well

underestimate him, and find out you see

of what else he can possibly do

and at last, the poor cub

a young wolf so dear

with a body that yearns to explore

his mind speaks of the wild and freedom at last

but his home’s only prison alone

speak what you may of the wolves

they may be dumb, stubborn, selfish

but when winter comes and the snow starts to fall

the pack will survive

and those who disrespect them, well

may the seven light their paths

blog.name: asongofstarkandtargaryen
blog.title: Dracarys!
blog.description: Jon/Dany/Bran/Arya Stan. Salty about the got ending. Also likes: The 100,  Star Wars, Stranger Things.

summary: What do you think is the central moral struggle for jon, arya, bran, sansa, dany and tyrion.  I think for arya it's about mercy...
question: What do you think is the central moral struggle for jon, arya, bran, sansa, dany and tyrion.  I think for arya it's about mercy vs revenge.  For sansa I think its about truth vs lies.  I'm struggling with the other four and i'm not so sure about arya and sansa.
answer:
Asoiaf/got characters are so complex and well written that their stories feature many moral struggles. The answers to the question of the major moral conflict each character faces would be varied within our fandom. That’s because each person tends to focus on different aspects on the stories they read.

I agree with your opinion on Sansa. She keeps getting better at lying and she’s currently relying on her fake identity to survive. But just because she says lies that doesn’t necessary means that she likes it. I believe that soon will come a time where she will have to choose between continuing the easy road of lying or following the hard path of truth. I’m rooting for the second. After all, Sansa never wanted to play the game of thrones herself.

I can see why you picked that struggle for Arya but for me her major one is choosing between being alone (and No One) and being part of the pack (and a Stark). Ned’s famous quote about the lone wolf dying and  the pack surviving keeps reappearing on some crucial scenes in her point of view for a reason. I think it’s because so far Arya has achieved more things while being alone while tragedy has befallen to her family members who weren’t alone (Catelyn and Robb, Bran and Rickon). But this quote coming from a person she really respected (her father) is a reminder that maybe on the darkest days to come will be better to be part of the pack instead of being alone.

Moving on to Jon, I think his major struggle is between doing his duty and doing what he believes it’s the right thing. Jon always wanted to appear a dutiful person and not to be associated with the bastard’s stigma (aka the bastard’s honor). However, he also has a strong sense of justice that often conflicts with his duty. This is evident on the fifth book where that struggle of his takes central place and in the end it’s partly the reason why he got killed. 

Daenerys most struggles come from her queedom. Daenerys doesn’t have an older relative or a mentor to help her navigate the path of a leader and often questions her actions as the Queen. The major struggle being torn between being a merciful queen and a successful one. It comes natural to her to help others since she has been through so much all her life. That often comes in conflict with her wanting to follow the steps of her successful ancestors. The dragons plant to trees is a quote that shows exactly this. Thankfully Daenerys isn’t only a dragon but a Mhysa as well. 

I admit that I’m not sure about the major struggle of Bran and Tyruon(if they have a single major conflict at all). However I’ll give it a try. 

Bran : so far his major inner struggle is about whether he should continue using Hodor’s body for his own means. Bran’s young age pretends us from seeing his actions in such a bad light as we would do if he was older. However, ripping someone off his free will is not a morally good action and I believe that Bran will come to realize it on the last two books.

 Tyrion : I think his major struggle is choosing whether he will lived hunted by his past ghosts or learning from the past. He’s a character who has faced many hardships in his life and for a lot of shit he’s going through his family is to blame. On the fifth book, he was at his lowest “defeated” by the past ghosts and having little hope for the future. But at some point on the future books he’ll have to decide whether he’ll let everything that happened in the past bring him down or if he’ll take a brave step forward, not forgetting his past but also no letting it define him.

blog.description:
Hello Visitor,
I am AzraelGFG::26 ♂, INFJ, German Archer, Gamer, Writer, Nerd, Biology Student, Shipper of SanSan and Gendrya and a loyal bannerman of Sansa Stark and her actress Sophie Turner!

summary: I don't think Alys hair has anything to do with Sansa, the actress herself said she didn't know anything about it, she's ginger...
question: I don't think Alys hair has anything to do with Sansa, the actress herself said she didn't know anything about it, she's ginger and that's all. But there are hints that she might end as QITN. lol she answered some questions on ig about the end and put a crown in the answer and there was photo of her and two guys (they played wildings) and their named her true queen in the north. If it's really going this way... lmao
answer: I very much doubt Alys Karstark is going to become Queen in the North. Unless you meant she marries Bran who’ll become king which is a different thing because she’ll be a consort, not the leader of the North. Secondly, book Alys married a wildling. Bran is a main character despite all the butchering of his personality and importance. There’s no way they are going to marry him to a character who’s already married to someone else in the books. That’s a huge disservice to his character. I refuse to believe that they’ll do that. Urgh they might actually do that. We’ll have to wait for ADoS to learn who GRRM intends to pair Bran with.

title: Sansa and Bran
body:
I thought I’d take the time to discuss my favourite Stark sibling relationship. While the two of them weren’t as close as Arya and Jon or Jon and Robb, they have a positive relationship despite having different interests. Out of all the Stark children, Sansa and Bran are noted to have enjoyed songs though Bran did not like the romantic ones Sansa enjoyed. 

Lord Wyman’s musicians played bravely and well, but harp and fiddle and horn were soon drowned beneath a tide of talk and laughter, the clash of cup and plate, and the snarling of hounds fighting for table scraps. The singer sang good songs, “Iron Lances” and “The Burning of the Ships” and “The Bear and the Maiden Fair,” but only Hodor seemed to be listening. He stood beside the piper, hopping from one foot to the other.

In fact songs and stories play an important role in Bran’s story especially when he meets the Children. Bran wanted to become a knight just as much as Sansa wanted to attend tourneys.

Bran was going to be a knight himself someday, one of the Kingsguard. Old Nan said they were the finest swords in all the realm. There were only seven of them, and they wore white armor and had no wives or children, but lived only to serve the king. Bran knew all the stories. Their names were like music to him. Serwyn of the Mirror Shield. Ser Ryam Redwyne. Prince Aemon the Dragonknight. The twins Ser Erryk and Ser Arryk, who had died on one another’s swords hundreds of years ago, when brother fought sister in the war the singers called the Dance of the Dragons. The White Bull, Gerold Hightower. Ser Arthur Dayne, the Sword of the Morning. Barristan the Bold. 

She pulled a chair close to the hearth, took down one of her favorite books, and lost herself in the stories of Florian and Jonquil, of Lady Shella and the Rainbow Knight, of valiant Prince Aemon and his doomed love for his brother’s queen. 

“Prince Aemon the Dragonknight cried the day Princess Naerys wed his brother Aegon,” Sansa Stark said, “and the twins Ser Arryk and Ser Erryk died with tears on their cheeks after each had given the other a mortal wound." 

Like Sansa, Bran was excited to go South.

For days, Bran could scarcely wait to be off. He was going to ride the kingsroad on a horse of his own, not a pony but a real horse. His father would be the Hand of the King, and they were going to live in the red castle at King’s Landing, the castle the Dragonlords had built. Old Nan said there were ghosts there, and dungeons where terrible things had been done, and dragon heads on the walls. It gave Bran a shiver just to think of it, but he was not afraid. How could he be afraid? His father would be with him, and the king with all his knights and sworn swords.

An opinion that Sansa no doubt shared. Unfortunately Bran was almost killed and he had to remain in the North. We know Bran’s fall devastated Sansa

She ought to be crying too, she thought, but the tears would not come. Perhaps she had used up all her tears for Lady and Bran.

and we know Lady’s death hurt Bran. 

Bran felt all cold inside. "She lost her wolf,” he said, weakly, remembering the day when four of his father’s guardsmen had returned from the south with Lady’s bones. Summer and Grey Wind and Shaggydog had begun to howl before they crossed the drawbridge, in voices drawn and desolate. Beneath the shadow of the First Keep was an ancient lichyard, its headstones spotted with pale lichen, where the old Kings of Winter had laid their faithful servants. It was there they buried Lady, while her brothers stalked between the graves like restless shadows. She had gone south, and only her bones had returned.

It was the only time that anyone shows any pain on Sansa’s behalf after Lady dies (with the exception of Ned’s anger whenever he remembered killing Lady). That’s what I love most about the relationship, they can’t see each other but they feel for the other as much as possible. I think this is the most uncomplicated relationship that Sansa has. She likes being a lady and that involves a lot of time in doors but besides the remark about kissing songs, Bran has no problem with what Sansa enjoys. He even remembered the feast they held in Robert’s in honor in which he noted how Sansa was listening intently to the singers without making a disparaging remark, something other characters find difficult. Sansa and Bran’s arcs contain a lot of trauma, something uncomplicated as their love for one another is sweet and will probably go a long way in healing them when they meet again.

The other thing that I love most about the two of them is how their arcs mirror each other. One could argue that all the remaining Stark siblings have similar journeys but I think Sansa and Bran’s resemble each other closely. In book one, Ned arranges Sansa’s betrothal so he’d have a cover to investigate the Lannisters and wants to use Bran to bridge the gap between Robb and Joffrey. However, their dreams unravel pretty quickly. Bran is disabled and Sansa’s court life meets one set back after another. As a disabled person, I am hesitant to compare the two situations but seeing as the Trident incident laid the foundation for a future of abuse, I’m going to continue. Both Bran and Sansa try to deal with their circumstances, the only difference is that Sansa’s coping mechanism means that she pretends everything is fine. 

In A Clash of Kings, both of them find themselves thrust in new situations. While Bran is the second son, he was only 8 when he acted as Lord of Winterfell and he was 7 when Ned was still teaching him, Robb is now King and he only has Luwin and Rodrick as advisors. 

“You are the lord in Winterfell now,” Robb told him. He was mounted on a shaggy grey stallion, his shield hung from the horse’s side; wood banded with iron, white and grey, and on it the snarling face of a direwolf. His brother wore grey chainmail over bleached leathers, sword and dagger at his waist, a fur-trimmed cloak across his shoulders. “You must take my place, as I took Father’s, until we come home.”

“I know,” Bran replied miserably. He had never felt so little or alone or scared. He did not know how to be a lord. 

Sansa is a prisoner of war still betrothed to Joffrey and she has to find a way to survive on her own, something she hasn’t been taught fully. 

The balcony was deserted save for Sansa. She stood with her head bowed, fighting to hold back her tears, while below Joffrey sat on his Iron Throne and dispensed what it pleased him to call justice. Nine cases out of ten seemed to bore him; those he allowed his council to handle, squirming restlessly while Lord Baelish, Grand Maester Pycelle, or Queen Cersei resolved the matter. When he did choose to make a ruling, though, not even his queen mother could sway him. 

“I’ll get you with child as soon as you’re able,” Joffrey said as he escorted her across the practice yard. “If the first one is stupid, I’ll chop off your head and find a smarter wife…

Interestingly, they both of the engage in diplomacy (though it’s called courtesy in Sansa’s chapters). The both of them have to bite their tongue often, in Bran’s case usually when he faces ableism or whenever he needs to make a ruling and in Sansa’s case, whenever her family is insulted or when she’s being abused. While they’re unhappy due to the war, the death of their father, the separation of their family, it should be noted that they’re good at their tasks and they survive the book. By the end of A Clash of Kings, their situations grew more bleak. Stannis lost and the Lannisters gained a powerful ally while Winterfell burned. The last few lines of Bran’s last ACoK apply to him and the Starks as whole.

The stone is strong, Bran told himself, the roots of the trees go deep, and under the ground the Kings of Winter sit their thrones. So long as those remained, Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken. Like me, he thought. I’m not dead either.

Despite everything, they’re still alive, they still have a fighting chance. In ASoS, Bran and Sansa are focused on one goal each: finding the three eyed crow and escaping King’s Landing (while Sansa has been looking for a way out, the situation became dire enough that merely surviving was not enough, she had to become proactive). Their arcs in the book are filled with hope that either fell through (Willas) or they let go (Jon). Eventually they reach their destinations and meet the men who have affected their lives so completely. For Bran it’s Brynden Rivers, one of the most powerful beings in the world who has been searching for a successor in the war against the Others and for Sansa it’s Littlefinger who caused the War of the Five Kings. Both Bran and Sansa have to go into hiding, Bran in the cave beyond the Wall and Sansa by hiding her identity. It’s important for them to learn from these men despite how morally reprehensible they both are. Neither of them are particularly happy but it’s important for their arc. Many dark elements are either introduced or continued- cannibalism, sexual abuse, human sacrifice, war mongering, etc. Unlike many people in the fandom, I think both Sansa and Bran will react with horror when they learn the full extent of what their mentors are doing and in TWoW, they’ll both reject their mentors and escape them one way or the other.

When Sansa and Bran meet again, it’s bound to be emotional and loving. They have both gone through hell and have been changed by it but deep down they’re still the same compassionate people they always were. As far as the Stark succession crisis, whether the Girl in Grey theory or the Sansa comes North with the Vale Army theory is true, I’m certain Sansa will support Bran’s claim. Regardless of what happens I’m looking forward to them meeting again.

“I know,” Bran replied miserably. He had never felt so little or alone or scared. He did not know how to be a lord. 

Sansa is a prisoner of war still betrothed to Joffrey and she has to find a way to survive on her own, something she hasn’t been taught fully. 

The balcony was deserted save for Sansa. She stood with her head bowed, fighting to hold back her tears, while below Joffrey sat on his Iron Throne and dispensed what it pleased him to call justice. Nine cases out of ten seemed to bore him; those he allowed his council to handle, squirming restlessly while Lord Baelish, Grand Maester Pycelle, or Queen Cersei resolved the matter. When he did choose to make a ruling, though, not even his queen mother could sway him. 

“I’ll get you with child as soon as you’re able,” Joffrey said as he escorted her across the practice yard. “If the first one is stupid, I’ll chop off your head and find a smarter wife…

Interestingly, they both of the engage in diplomacy (though it’s called courtesy in Sansa’s chapters). The both of them have to bite their tongue often, in Bran’s case usually when he faces ableism or whenever he needs to make a ruling and in Sansa’s case, whenever her family is insulted or when she’s being abused. While they’re unhappy due to the war, the death of their father, the separation of their family, it should be noted that they’re good at their tasks and they survive the book. By the end of A Clash of Kings, their situations grew more bleak. Stannis lost and the Lannisters gained a powerful ally while Winterfell burned. The last few lines of Bran’s last ACoK apply to him and the Starks as whole.

The stone is strong, Bran told himself, the roots of the trees go deep, and under the ground the Kings of Winter sit their thrones. So long as those remained, Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken. Like me, he thought. I’m not dead either.

Despite everything, they’re still alive, they still have a fighting chance. In ASoS, Bran and Sansa are focused on one goal each: finding the three eyed crow and escaping King’s Landing (while Sansa has been looking for a way out, the situation became dire enough that merely surviving was not enough, she had to become proactive). Their arcs in the book are filled with hope that either fell through (Willas) or they let go (Jon). Eventually they reach their destinations and meet the men who have affected their lives so completely. For Bran it’s Brynden Rivers, one of the most powerful beings in the world who has been searching for a successor in the war against the Others and for Sansa it’s Littlefinger who caused the War of the Five Kings. Both Bran and Sansa have to go into hiding, Bran in the cave beyond the Wall and Sansa by hiding her identity. It’s important for them to learn from these men despite how morally reprehensible they both are. Neither of them are particularly happy but it’s important for their arc. Many dark elements are either introduced or continued- cannibalism, sexual abuse, human sacrifice, war mongering, etc. Unlike many people in the fandom, I think both Sansa and Bran will react with horror when they learn the full extent of what their mentors are doing and in TWoW, they’ll both reject their mentors and escape them one way or the other.

When Sansa and Bran meet again, it’s bound to be emotional and loving. They have both gone through hell and have been changed by it but deep down they’re still the same compassionate people they always were. As far as the Stark succession crisis, whether the Girl in Grey theory or the Sansa comes North with the Vale Army theory is true, I’m certain Sansa will support Bran’s claim. Regardless of what happens I’m looking forward to them meeting again.

I thought I’d take the time to discuss my favourite Stark sibling relationship. While the two of them weren’t as close as Arya and Jon or Jon and Robb, they have a positive relationship despite having different interests. Out of all the Stark children, Sansa and Bran are noted to have enjoyed songs though Bran did not like the romantic ones Sansa enjoyed. 

Lord Wyman’s musicians played bravely and well, but harp and fiddle and horn were soon drowned beneath a tide of talk and laughter, the clash of cup and plate, and the snarling of hounds fighting for table scraps. The singer sang good songs, “Iron Lances” and “The Burning of the Ships” and “The Bear and the Maiden Fair,” but only Hodor seemed to be listening. He stood beside the piper, hopping from one foot to the other.

In fact songs and stories play an important role in Bran’s story especially when he meets the Children. Bran wanted to become a knight just as much as Sansa wanted to attend tourneys.

Bran was going to be a knight himself someday, one of the Kingsguard. Old Nan said they were the finest swords in all the realm. There were only seven of them, and they wore white armor and had no wives or children, but lived only to serve the king. Bran knew all the stories. Their names were like music to him. Serwyn of the Mirror Shield. Ser Ryam Redwyne. Prince Aemon the Dragonknight. The twins Ser Erryk and Ser Arryk, who had died on one another’s swords hundreds of years ago, when brother fought sister in the war the singers called the Dance of the Dragons. The White Bull, Gerold Hightower. Ser Arthur Dayne, the Sword of the Morning. Barristan the Bold. 

She pulled a chair close to the hearth, took down one of her favorite books, and lost herself in the stories of Florian and Jonquil, of Lady Shella and the Rainbow Knight, of valiant Prince Aemon and his doomed love for his brother’s queen. 

“Prince Aemon the Dragonknight cried the day Princess Naerys wed his brother Aegon,” Sansa Stark said, “and the twins Ser Arryk and Ser Erryk died with tears on their cheeks after each had given the other a mortal wound." 

Like Sansa, Bran was excited to go South.

For days, Bran could scarcely wait to be off. He was going to ride the kingsroad on a horse of his own, not a pony but a real horse. His father would be the Hand of the King, and they were going to live in the red castle at King’s Landing, the castle the Dragonlords had built. Old Nan said there were ghosts there, and dungeons where terrible things had been done, and dragon heads on the walls. It gave Bran a shiver just to think of it, but he was not afraid. How could he be afraid? His father would be with him, and the king with all his knights and sworn swords.

An opinion that Sansa no doubt shared. Unfortunately Bran was almost killed and he had to remain in the North. We know Bran’s fall devastated Sansa

She ought to be crying too, she thought, but the tears would not come. Perhaps she had used up all her tears for Lady and Bran.

and we know Lady’s death hurt Bran. 

Bran felt all cold inside. "She lost her wolf,” he said, weakly, remembering the day when four of his father’s guardsmen had returned from the south with Lady’s bones. Summer and Grey Wind and Shaggydog had begun to howl before they crossed the drawbridge, in voices drawn and desolate. Beneath the shadow of the First Keep was an ancient lichyard, its headstones spotted with pale lichen, where the old Kings of Winter had laid their faithful servants. It was there they buried Lady, while her brothers stalked between the graves like restless shadows. She had gone south, and only her bones had returned.

It was the only time that anyone shows any pain on Sansa’s behalf after Lady dies (with the exception of Ned’s anger whenever he remembered killing Lady). That’s what I love most about the relationship, they can’t see each other but they feel for the other as much as possible. I think this is the most uncomplicated relationship that Sansa has. She likes being a lady and that involves a lot of time in doors but besides the remark about kissing songs, Bran has no problem with what Sansa enjoys. He even remembered the feast they held in Robert’s in honor in which he noted how Sansa was listening intently to the singers without making a disparaging remark, something other characters find difficult. Sansa and Bran’s arcs contain a lot of trauma, something uncomplicated as their love for one another is sweet and will probably go a long way in healing them when they meet again.

The other thing that I love most about the two of them is how their arcs mirror each other. One could argue that all the remaining Stark siblings have similar journeys but I think Sansa and Bran’s resemble each other closely. In book one, Ned arranges Sansa’s betrothal so he’d have a cover to investigate the Lannisters and wants to use Bran to bridge the gap between Robb and Joffrey. However, their dreams unravel pretty quickly. Bran is disabled and Sansa’s court life meets one set back after another. As a disabled person, I am hesitant to compare the two situations but seeing as the Trident incident laid the foundation for a future of abuse, I’m going to continue. Both Bran and Sansa try to deal with their circumstances, the only difference is that Sansa’s coping mechanism means that she pretends everything is fine. 

In A Clash of Kings, both of them find themselves thrust in new situations. While Bran is the second son, he was only 8 when he acted as Lord of Winterfell and he was 7 when Ned was still teaching him, Robb is now King and he only has Luwin and Rodrick as advisors. 

“You are the lord in Winterfell now,” Robb told him. He was mounted on a shaggy grey stallion, his shield hung from the horse’s side; wood banded with iron, white and grey, and on it the snarling face of a direwolf. His brother wore grey chainmail over bleached leathers, sword and dagger at his waist, a fur-trimmed cloak across his shoulders. “You must take my place, as I took Father’s, until we come home.”

“I know,” Bran replied miserably. He had never felt so little or alone or scared. He did not know how to be a lord.

Nine cases out of ten seemed to bore him; those he allowed his council to handle, squirming restlessly while Lord Baelish, Grand Maester Pycelle, or Queen Cersei resolved the matter. While they’re unhappy due to the war, the death of their father, the separation of their family, it should be noted that they’re good at their tasks and they survive the book. By the end of A Clash of Kings, their situations grew more bleak. Stannis lost and the Lannisters gained a powerful ally while Winterfell burned. The stone is strong, Bran told himself, the roots of the trees go deep, and under the ground the Kings of Winter sit their thrones. So long as those remained, Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken. Like me, he thought. I’m not dead either.

Despite everything, they’re still alive, they still have a fighting chance. In ASoS, Bran and Sansa are focused on one goal each: finding the three eyed crow and escaping King’s Landing (while Sansa has been looking for a way out, the situation became dire enough that merely surviving was not enough, she had to become proactive). Their arcs in the book are filled with hope that either fell through (Willas) or they let go (Jon). Eventually they reach their destinations and meet the men who have affected their lives so completely. For Bran it’s Brynden Rivers, one of the most powerful beings in the world who has been searching for a successor in the war against the Others and for Sansa it’s Littlefinger who caused the War of the Five Kings. It’s important for them to learn from these men despite how morally reprehensible they both are. Neither of them are particularly happy but it’s important for their arc. Many dark elements are either introduced or continued- cannibalism, sexual abuse, human sacrifice, war mongering, etc. Unlike many people in the fandom, I think both Sansa and Bran will react with horror when they learn the full extent of what their mentors are doing and in TWoW, they’ll both reject their mentors and escape them one way or the other.

When Sansa and Bran meet again, it’s bound to be emotional and loving. Regardless of what happens I’m looking forward to them meeting again.
